titleMap.4: Over 30 minutes and up to 2 hours
Over 30 minutes and up to 2 hours

form.helpvalue:
If smoke alarm detected fire and alerted a person, choose Automatic detector / alarm system.

If person discovered fire and then manually activated break glass call point, choose Person.

Select the type of the property or location where the fire started.

If fire spread from a secondary fire to an FDR location, record the FDR location here.

If fire spread from one FDR location to another, choose the first FDR location here.

If the property was an HMO, choose the option from this list.

If the fire started in a non-residential building (e.g. shop or surgery), you need to record the type/use of the building.

form.title: Tick if the property is a recycling facility

form.helpvalue: Record details of the location where the fire started.

titleMap.70: On or near tracks or paths
titleMap.71: In open area next to housing
titleMap.NO_ALARM: No smoke / fire alarm actuated or Call Handling Centre error

form.helpvalue: The property type that you have selected is an HMO property.
Did the fire occur in a communal area?
If the fire didn't occur in a specific flat / maisonette, but in a communal area such as a shared hallway or bin room, select Yes here.

Record details of the property and where the fire started.

If the building construction at the property influenced the fire then record it.

titleMap.70: On or near tracks or paths
titleMap.71: In open area next to housing
titleMap.NO_ALARM: No smoke / fire alarm actuated or Call Handling Centre error

titleMap.6: Yes - Large single storey retail premises

form.helpvalue: Assess the safety of the building at the fire
Report on whether there were any Fire Safety issues that contributed to risk at the incident.

titleMap.3: Exits blocked (e.g. Materials stored blocking exit)
titleMap.4: Exit route blocked by smoke / flames
titleMap.5: Poor implementation e.g. doors swing the wrong way
titleMap.6: Contents contributing to abnormal fire spread /smoke production

titleMap.4: Breached - fire doors left open or incorrectly fitted
titleMap.6: Fire spread through gaps or voids in construction

form.helpvalue: What was the approximate size of the room / area / compartment of origin?

This refers to where the fire started (e.g. the kitchen, bedroom or office).

Assess the horizontal area.
What was the approximate size of the floor of origin?

If the fire started in an individual flat, just give a measure of the floor size in that flat.

Assess the horizontal area.

Roof/loft space for storage = NOT a floor

Roof/loft space converted to room = a floor

Basement = a floor

Ground floor = 0

Below ground / basement = use minus sign and count down

Roof / loft space used for storage = 999
Was there involvement of any road vehicles?

titleMap.81050_38: Shortcut to Other inside / Cargo area

form.title: Did the vehicle appear to be abandoned?

form.helpvalue: Was the fire caused by an RTC?

Small vehicles - includes those that can be driven using a normal driver's license, such as a car, van or minibus and also includes caravans and mobility scooters, etc.

Large vehicles - includes Lorries, buses and coaches etc., along with agricultural and construction vehicles.

Motorbikes, mopeds and bicycles should be counted in the third box.
Did the Brigade extricate any of these people from their vehicles?
Extrication here refers to the removal of people from vehicles using tools.
Was there involvement of any hazardous or dangerous materials?

This includes:

  • Explosives (e.g. fireworks etc., in storage or in transit)
  • Flammable products (e.g. acetylene, petrol, diesel etc.)
  • Other dangerous substances (e.g. asbestos, acids etc.)

Don't include hazardous or dangerous materials introduced to start the fire.
Was there a smoke / heat detector or fire alarm system present in the property?
Include domestic smoke alarms here, but not break glass systems as they are not automatic.

titleMap.7: Mains security system including smoke detector/alarm

titleMap.1: In room of origin of fire

titleMap.2: Yes, but did not raise alarm

titleMap.5: Fire products did not reach detector
titleMap.10: Fire in area not covered by system
titleMap.20: Alarm was raised before the system operated

form.helpvalue: Were there any firefighting systems installed at the property?

Include active / automatic systems in the property that you know about (e.g. sprinklers).

Include any manual facilities that you used (e.g. dry risers, firefighting lifts / shafts).

titleMap.1: In room of origin of fire

items.helpvalue: Please click 'Finish' to save details of this system.

titleMap.2: Delay due to: Sent to wrong direction / address

form.helpvalue:
The following are items of equipment commonly used at fire incidents. Enter the quantity used of each in the boxes provided.

Don't include covering / safety jets if they were charged but otherwise unused.
Did you use any other equipment at the incident?

Other than B.A., hosereels and jets you have already included, include any other equipment crucial to your activity at the incident.

Consider both Brigade equipment and equipment provided at the site (e.g. fire blankets, buckets or extinguishers).

For example, if a piece of equipment allowed you to rescue or extricate someone then it is important to record this here.

items.helpvalue: Please click 'Finish' to save details of this equipment.

form.helpvalue:
Indicate a likely or probable cause of the fire.

Not known should only be used if a Fire Investigation Officer has been contacted.

form.title: Are there signs that the incident was alcohol / drugs related?

titleMap.name: Electricity or gas supply cut off

form.helpvalue: Number of rooms in the individual dwelling
Request the number or estimate if necessary - exclude bathrooms, toilets, halls, landings or storage areas.
Record the number of residents who live in the dwelling.
Of this number, record the number of residents in each age group.

form.title: Is there evidence that there are smokers in the household?
Has household had a fire when Brigade was not notified?
Was anyone in the household deaf or hard of hearing?

form.helpvalue:
Think about the activity, fault or action that led to there being a fire.

Avoid using 'Not Known', as there are general options that you can use if necessary.

Source of ignition is the heat source that directly started the fire at the property / location you are reporting on. If this is a cooking fire you would record the appliance that was being used.

Remember, if a firework is put through a letterbox or a lighted rag is put into a car, the source of ignition is the firework or the rag as these directly started the fire at the property you are reporting on.

form.title: Tick if the source of ignition is smoking related

form.helpvalue:
The item or material first ignited refers to the first item ignited by the source of ignition.

If you are reporting on a building fire, record the first part of the building or item belonging to the building that was set on fire or suffered damage.
Did any of the following lead to rapid fire growth?
At the property, was there any direct burning (fire / flames)?

If there were no flames, only heat and smoke damage, then No should be selected here.

If oil in a pan was on fire, record Yes here.
Assess the extent of FIRE and HEAT damage when you arrived.

titleMap.5: Affecting more than 2 floors (not whole building)
titleMap.11: Affecting more than 2 decks, not whole boat
titleMap.15: More than one carriage, not whole train
titleMap.3-2: Limited to floor of origin (not whole building)

form.helpvalue: Fire and heat damage at end of incident
Assess the extent of damage caused by FIRE and HEAT at the end of the incident.

titleMap.5: Affecting more than 2 floors (not whole building)
titleMap.11: Affecting more than 2 decks, not whole boat
titleMap.15: More than one carriage, not whole train
titleMap.3-2: Limited to floor of origin (not whole building)

form.helpvalue:
If there was any damage beyond the first primary (FDR) property that ignited, record when this occurred and how far away the property was.

This includes any fire, heat or smoke damage, as well as any other damage that may have resulted, for example from water.

Include damage to other properties in the same block of flats or other businesses in the same office block.

titleMap.2: up to 1 metre (e.g. next door / adjoining property)
up to 1 metre (e.g. next door / adjoining property)

form.helpvalue:
If other properties were affected by the damage spread, record how many.

In the free text box describe the damage, along with any relevant addresses or registration details etc.
Enter the area damaged in square metres.
Total area damaged by fire, heat, smoke and water.
Enter the area damaged in square metres.
At the incident, were there any attacks on firefighters?

"Attack" means any aggressive acts, such as objects thrown, verbal or physical abuse or harassment.

This includes attacks on the way to an incident, at an incident, or whilst returning from an incident.

Complete this information in line with the near hit reporting procedures described in Standing Order 19/3 (Section 2.5).

Enter the type of attack and record any resulting injuries.

Record injury as serious if someone had to go to hospital for treatment.

If there were no resulting injuries, leave as '0'.

form.title: Were the Police contacted about the incident?
Did you have to contact an Ambulance?

form.helpvalue: Was there anyone in the building at the time of the fire?

Answer to the best of your knowledge.

This refers to anybody in the entire building / property from the time the fire was discovered.

This includes anyone in an office block or block of flats.
People who evacuated from the building unharmed

Evacuation = people moving from a dangerous place to somewhere safe.

WITH Brigade assistance differs from a rescue and includes:

  • People 'led or ushered to safety' by Brigade personnel who were not physically rescued.
  • An evacuation co-ordinated by Brigade personnel.

DO NOT include any casualties or rescues here.
How many people evacuated / left the building unharmed:

Time for evacuation is an estimate from the time that the fire was discovered.

If the evacuation process was delayed for any reason, (e.g. exits blocked), then answer Yes to Was there any delay?

titleMap.4: Over 30 minutes and up to 2 hours

form.helpvalue: Were there any rescues, casualties or fatalities?

Casualties include:

  • Anyone who received first aid or medical treatment at the scene.
  • Anyone who required more medical treatment than could be given at the scene (e.g. they went to hospital).
  • Anyone advised to attend hospital or see a doctor for a precautionary check, even if they did not attend.

This is a count of people, so remember that an individual should only be recorded once on this screen.

If a casualty was also rescued, just count them once as a casualty on this page. When you fill in the casualty details, you can record that the person was also rescued.

Non-fatal casualties include anyone advised to attend a precautionary check, regardless of whether they went.
At the incident, how many people were:

items.helpvalue: Which person from the count page are you recording?

name: Non-fatal casualty (including a casualty who was rescued)

items.helpvalue: Did the injury occur as a result of the fire, heat or smoke?

Choose Yes if the injury was due to the effects of the fire e.g. smoke inhalation, or shock due to the fire; or due to escaping the incident e.g. a twisted ankle escaping a smoke filled car; or if you advised a precautionary check due to the incident.

Choose No if the injury would have occurred even if the fire had not happened. For example a person had a stroke and then the fire started; or the person was injured in an RTC and there was subsequently a fire.
Did the Brigade provide oxygen to this person at the scene?
This includes oxygen therapy and BVM.
